On Tuesday 23 August 2005 18:06, Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Cedric Beust wrote:
> > 1)  Is it okay to have more that one assertion per test?
> > 2)  When you have more than one assertion per test, is it okay to run
> > asserts that follow a failed assert?
>
> It's also the case that subsequent assertion failures may not mean much.
> If the assertion fails, then something broke. It's quite likely that
> whatever did break will cause other cascading failures down the line
> even if the specific code those assertions are trying to test is in fact
> correct. JUnit goes to great efforts to make sure that each test method
> is completely independent of other test methods. There are good reasons
> for that.

EG in [test] code I wrote yesterday, an 

    assertIsoModels( mWanted, mExpressionForGot );

blew up because mExpressionForGot involved a null pointer.
[assertIsoModels is code in my base class that does "if
 m1 not isomorphic to m2, fail with a legible error message".]

I first added

    assertNotNull( thePointerThatWasNull );

before the isomorphism test, then fixed the null problem.
I really don't want assertNotNull to *continue* after 
spotting the problem!

PS also this is a failure vs error thing: a NPE results
from a different kind of brokenness than eg non-isomorphic
models. I like it that the scary errors show up like this.

-- 
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
Stross won one! Farah won one! Langford won TWO!
